10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-009-9313-5931310.1007/s10904-009-9313-5ArticleFrom 1-d to 3-d Supramolecular Structures Derived from Diphenic Acid and Auxiliary LigandsGuoFeng1aZhangXiuling1ZhuBaoyong1QiuJianchao2Department of ChemistryDe zhou University253023ShandongPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.9227.e0000000119573309Qingdao Institute of BioEnergy and Bioprocess TechnologyChinese Academy of Sciences266101QingdaoPeople’s Republic of China+86-534-8985835+86-534-8985835guofeng1510@yeah.net2122009320102013845171120092462009161120092122009© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20092009Abstract

Four novel compounds [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4′-bipy)2]n (1), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H2O)](H2O)}n, (2), [Ni(dpa)(im)3]n (3) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4) [H2dpa = 2,4′-diphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine, 2,2′-bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine and im = imidazole] were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. X-ray crystallography shows that the 2,4′-diphenic acid exhibits three coordination modes to link the metal ions: μ1−η1: η1/μ0−η0: η0, μ1−η1: η0/μ2−η1: η1 and μ1−η1: η0/μ1−η1: η0. Compound 1 has a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 are 3D supramolecular structures. Compound 4 is a 2D supramolecular structure. All the compounds, 1–4, are self-assembled to form supramolecular structures through hydrogen bonding interactions.

KeywordsCoordination polymersHydrogen bondsSupramolecular structuresCo(II), Ni(II), Zn(II) complexesX-ray single crystal diffractionvolume-issue-count4issue-article-count24issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2010issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2010article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleContentOnlyarticle-registration-date-year2009article-registration-date-month11article-registration-date-day17article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleContentOnlyarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10904_2009_Article_9313.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2010issue-online-date-month2issue-online-date-day23issue-print-date-year2010issue-print-date-month2issue-print-date-day22issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryPolymer Sciences journal-subject-secondaryOrganic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

Crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures, based on metal and organic building blocks, is a rapidly expanding research area owing to the diverse topologies and potential application of these materials in luminescence, non-linear optics, catalysis and magnetism. [1–7]. Coordination polymers are synthesized by the rational selection of metal ions and the use of structurally interesting ligands with specific functionality to construct metal–organic frameworks. The synthesis of coordination polymers with fascinating structures requires careful selection of the organic ligands [8, 9].

Hydrogen bonds are well-suited for the design of polymeric arrangements via crystal engineering because of their important directional interactions and because they interlink into 1-D or 2-D structures of high dimensionality [10–18]. As building blocks to construct coordination polymers, 2,4′-diphenyl-dicarboxylic acid (2,4′-H2dpa) is considered because (a) it affords various coordination modes due to its multifunctional carboxylate groups and can bridge metal ions, and (b) it is a flexible ligand that allows the formation of multi-dimensional structures constructed in different directions. To the best of our knowledge, there are no systematic studies of compounds with the 2,4′-H2dpa ligand that lead to supramolecular coordination polymers. Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of a series of compounds, [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4′-bipy)2] (1), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H2O)](H2O)}n, (2), [Ni(dpa) (im)3]n (3) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4).

ExperimentalMaterials

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the 400–4000 cm−1 range with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a dry KBr pellet.

SynthesisSynthesis of [Co(Hdpa) <sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bipy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.238 g), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol), 4,4’-bipy (0.156 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction products were red block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 51% based on Co). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C48 H34 CoN4O8: C, 67.53; H, 4.01; N, 6.56. Found: C, 67.60; H, 3.89; N, 6.64. IR (cm−1): 3402(br), 1619(s), 1481(s), 1164(w), 846(m), 660(m).

Synthesis of {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy) (H<sub>2</sub>O)](H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub>n</sub>(<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of NiCl2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol), 2,2′-bipy (1 mmol, 0.156 g) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner. Green block crystals of 2 were obtained in 53% yield (based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C24H20NiN2O6: C, 58.69; H, 4.10; N, 5.70. Found: C, 57.92; H, 4.16; N, 5.75. IR (cm−1): 3460(br), 1645(s), 1446(s), 1216(w), 867(m), 642(m).

Synthesis of [Ni(dpa)(im)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was prepared in a similar manner as 2 except for the use of im instead of 2,2′-bipy. Green block crystals of 3 were obtained in 61% yield (based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C23 H22 Ni N6O5: C, 53.01; H, 4.25; N, 16.13. Found: C, 53.62; H, 4.19; N, 16.01. IR (cm−1): 1621(s), 1463(s), 1132(w), 821(m), 662(m).

Synthesis of [Zn(dpa)(im)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of ZnCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, g), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), imidazole (0.136 g, 2 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction products were colorless block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give the pure product; yield, 60% (based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C17H12ZnN2O4: C, 54.65; H, 3.24; N, 7.50. Found: C, 53.76; H, 3.16; N, 7.42. IR (cm−1): 1626(s), 1452(s), 1165(w), 871(m), 639(m).

X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals were mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with a Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using an ω-scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [19]. All non-hydrogen atoms were located by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier syntheses. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were located by geometrical calculations and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structure refinement. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. All calculations were performed by the SHELXTL 97 program [20]. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analysis are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are shown in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionStructure Description[Co(Hdpa)<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bipy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>n</sub> (1)

The X-ray crystallographic study reveals that the 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, C2/c space group. Each Co(II) cation exhibits triangular prism geometry with an N2O4 coordination sphere from two dpa ligands [Co(1)–O(3) = 2.037(4) Å and Co(1)–O(4) = 2.315(6) Å] and two 4,4′-bipy ligands [Co–N = 2.101(4) Å] (Fig. 1a). Dpa ligands are coordinated to Co(II) in a bidentate chelating mode. The dihedral angles between the two phenyl rings in dpa and the two pyridine rings in 4,4′-bipy are 58.00° and 29.75°, respectively.

Strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the O–H group from Hdpa and the N-atoms of 4,4′-bipy are observed in 1 with a D…A distance of 2.667(4) Å (symmetry code: x,2−y,−1/2+z) and an angle of 171(4)° (Table 3). Through hydrogen bonds, the molecular zigzag chains form along the z-axis (Fig. 1b).

{[Ni(dpa) (2,2′-bipy) (H<sub>2</sub>O)](H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub>n</sub> (2)

Figure 2a shows a perspective view of the title compound, {[Ni(dpa) (2,2′-bipy) (H2O)](H2O)}n with the numbering scheme. Ni(II) is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni–O = 2.043(15)–2.165(15) Å], two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)–N(1) = 2.059(16) Å and Ni(1)–N(2) = 2.064(16) Å] and one coordinated water molecule [Ni(1)–O(1w) = 2.071(15) Å], showing a distorted octahedral geometry. O(2), O(1w), N(1) and N(2) form the equatorial plane. The axial positions are occupied by two carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni(1)–O(1) = 2.165 (15) Å and Ni(1)–O(3) = 2.043(15) Å]. Dpa act as a μ3-ligand (μ1−η1: η0 and μ2−η1: η1) with one carboxylate group bridging two Ni(II)-atoms through a bis-monodentate mode, and the other carboxylate bridging bridging the second Ni(II)-atom through a monodentate mode. Moreover, each Ni(II)-atom center is connected with three dpa ligands. The organic ligands link the inorganic Ni(II) nodes to form a 2D sheet.

In compound 2, one lattice water takes part in hydrogen bonding through which the 2D sheet is extended into a 3D supramolecular network (Fig. 2b) with a H21w…O4 distance of 1.98 Å (symmetry code: −1/2 + x, 1/2 − y, −1/2 + z) and a H22w…O1 distance of 2.18 Å(symmetry code: −1 + x, y, z:) (Table 3).

[Ni(dpa)(im)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 has a 3D supramolecular architecture derived from 1D helical chains via rich hydrogen bonds. Part of the chain with atom labeling is illustrated in Fig. 3a. The central Ni(1)-atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry in which the equatorial positions are occupied by two carboxyl oxygen atoms [Ni(1)–O(2) = 2.106(15) Å and Ni(1)–O(3) = 2.050 (16) Å] and two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)–N(3) = 2.068 (18) Å and Ni(1)–N(5) = 2.080(19) Å]. The axial positions are occupied by one water molecule [Ni(1)–O(1w) = 2.166(15) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Ni(1)–N(2) = 2.063(18) Å] with an O–Ni–N angle of 177.36 (6)°. The Ni ions are connected by dpa linkers to form a helical chain running along the [100] direction with a pitch of 13.824(5) Å. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle between them being 45.84°.

There exist in the complex intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Dpa is coordinated to a Ni center with each carboxylate group in a monodentate mode leaving the uncoordinated O-atom involved in hydrogen bonding to the neighboring dpa molecules [H(1w)…O(4) distance of 1.85 Å and H(2w)…O(1) distance of 1.79 Å]. There also exists an intermolecular hydrogen bond between the imidazole molecule and the coordinated oxygen atom [H(4A)…O(2) distance of 2.06 Å] (Fig. 3b). Intramolecular hydrogen bonds form between the N–H groups and the O-atom of dpa and the coordinated water with an H(1)…O(4) distance of 1.93 Å and an H(6A)…O(1w) distance of 2.07 Å (Table 3).

[Zn(dpa)(im)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 4 consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(II)-atom, one imidazole ligand and three dpa ligands (Fig. 4a). The central Zn-atom is in a tetrahedral coordination environment having three Zn–O bonds with carboxylate groups [1.946(17)–1.981(16) Å] and one Zn–N bond from the imidazole ligand [Zn–N = 1.998(18) Å]. The bond angles between the donor atoms around the Zn(II) center range from 96.03° (7) to 132.22 (7)°. Dpa ligands bridge the two Zn(II) centers through μ1−η1:η0 and μ2−η1:η1 coordination modes. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle of 49.41°. The two coordination modes allows dpa to link the Zn(II) centers into a 1D chain containing repeating eight-membered (–Zn–O–C–O–) rings (Fig. 4b). The Zn…Zn separation in the rings is 3.644 Å.

Crystal packing analysis of 4 shows the formation of interchain hydrogen bonds (Fig. 4c). The N–H group of the imidazole molecule of one chain is linked through the uncoordinated oxygen atom of the adjacent chain at a D…A distance of 2.729(3) and a N–H–O angle of 165° (symmetry code: x, −1 + y,−1 + z), which generates a two-dimensional structure (Table 3).

Conclusions

In the present work, four novel hydrogen bonding supramolecular networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. X-ray crystallography shows that compound 1 is a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 have a 3D supramolecular structure. Compound 4 has a 2D supramolecular structure. The successful preparation of these complexes provides a valuable approach to the construction of other supramolecular compounds.

Supplementary data

Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures in this article have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publications CCDC Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4′-bipy)2 (735450), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)3(H2O)](H2O)}n(735451), [Ni(dpa)(im)3]n(735452) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (735453). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK(fax: +44 1223 336033 or e-mail: deposit@ccdc,cam.ac.uk).

Each Co(II) cation exhibits triangular prism geometry with an N2O4 coordination sphere from two dpa ligands [Co(1)-O(3) = 2.037(4) Å and Co(1)-O(4) = 2.315(6) Å] and two 4,4'-bipy ligands [Co-N = 2.101(4) Å] (Fig. 1a). Dpa ligands are coordinated to Co(II) in a bidentate chelating mode. The dihedral angles between the two phenyl rings in dpa and the two pyridine rings in 4,4'-bipy are 58.00° and 29.75°, respectively.Strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the O-H group from Hdpa and the N-atoms of 4,4'-bipy are observed in 1 with a D…A distance of 2.667(4) Å (symmetry code: x,2-y,-1/2+z) and an angle of 171(4)° (Table 3). Through hydrogen bonds, the molecular zigzag chains form along the z-axis (Fig. 1b).{[Ni(dpa) (2,2'-bipy) (H2O)](H2O)}n (2)Figure 2a shows a perspective view of the title compound, {[Ni(dpa) (2,2'-bipy) (H2O)](H2O)}n with the numbering scheme. Ni(II) is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni-O = 2.043(15)-2.165(15) Å], two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)-N(1) = 2.059(16) Å and Ni(1)-N(2) = 2.064(16) Å] and one coordinated water molecule [Ni(1)-O(1w) = 2.071(15) Å], showing a distorted octahedral geometry. O(2), O(1w), N(1) and N(2) form the equatorial plane. The axial positions are occupied by two carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni(1)-O(1) = 2.165 (15) Å and Ni(1)-O(3) = 2.043(15) Å]. Dpa act as a μ3-ligand (μ1-η1: η0 and μ2-η1: η1) with one carboxylate group bridging two Ni(II)-atoms through a bis-monodentate mode, and the other carboxylate bridging bridging the second Ni(II)-atom through a monodentate mode. Moreover, each Ni(II)-atom center is connected with three dpa ligands. The organic ligands link the inorganic Ni(II) nodes to form a 2D sheet.In compound 2, one lattice water takes part in hydrogen bonding through which the 2D sheet is extended into a 3D supramolecular network (Fig. 2b) with a H21w…O4 distance of 1.98 Å (symmetry code: -1/2 + x, 1/2 - y, -1/2 + z) and a H22w…O1 distance of 2.18 Å(symmetry code: -1 + x, y, z:) (Table 3).[Ni(dpa)(im)3]n (3)Complex 3 has a 3D supramolecular architecture derived from 1D helical chains via rich hydrogen bonds. Part of the chain with atom labeling is illustrated in Fig. 3a. The central Ni(1)-atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry in which the equatorial positions are occupied by two carboxyl oxygen atoms [Ni(1)-O(2) = 2.106(15) Å and Ni(1)-O(3) = 2.050 (16) Å] and two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)-N(3) = 2.068 (18) Å and Ni(1)-N(5) = 2.080(19) Å]. The axial positions are occupied by one water molecule [Ni(1)-O(1w) = 2.166(15) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Ni(1)-N(2) = 2.063(18) Å] with an O-Ni-N angle of 177.36 (6)°. The Ni ions are connected by dpa linkers to form a helical chain running along the [100] direction with a pitch of 13.824(5) Å. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle between them being 45.84°.There exist in the complex intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Dpa is coordinated to a Ni center with each carboxylate group in a monodentate mode leaving the uncoordinated O-atom involved in hydrogen bonding to the neighboring dpa molecules [H(1w)…O(4) distance of 1.85 Å and H(2w)…O(1) distance of 1.79 Å]. There also exists an intermolecular hydrogen bond between the imidazole molecule and the coordinated oxygen atom [H(4A)…O(2) distance of 2.06 Å] (Fig. 3b). Intramolecular hydrogen bonds form between the N-H groups and the O-atom of dpa and the coordinated water with an H(1)…O(4) distance of 1.93 Å and an H(6A)…O(1w) distance of 2.07 Å (Table 3).[Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4)Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 4 consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(II)-atom, one imidazole ligand and three dpa ligands (Fig. 4a). The central Zn-atom is in a tetrahedral coordination environment having three Zn-O bonds with carboxylate groups [1.946(17)-1.981(16) Å] and one Zn-N bond from the imidazole ligand [Zn-N = 1.998(18) Å]. The bond angles between the donor atoms around the Zn(II) center range from 96.03° (7) to 132.22 (7)°. Dpa ligands bridge the two Zn(II) centers through μ1-η1:η0 and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle of 49.41°. The two coordination modes allows dpa to link the Zn(II) centers into a 1D chain containing repeating eight-membered (-Zn-O-C-O-) rings (Fig. 4b). The Zn…Zn separation in the rings is 3.644 Å.Crystal packing analysis of 4 shows the formation of interchain hydrogen bonds (Fig. 4c). The N-H group of the imidazole molecule of one chain is linked through the uncoordinated oxygen atom of the adjacent chain at a D…A distance of 2.729(3) and a N-H-O angle of 165° (symmetry code: x, -1 + y,-1 + z), which generates a two-dimensional structure (Table 3).ConclusionsIn the present work, four novel hydrogen bonding supramolecular networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. X-ray crystallography shows that compound 1 is a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 have a 3D supramolecular structure. Compound 4 has a 2D supramolecular structure. The successful preparation of these complexes provides a valuable approach to the construction of other supramolecular compounds.Supplementary dataCrystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures in this article have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publications CCDC Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4'-bipy)2 (735450), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)3(H2O)](H2O)}n(735451), [Ni(dpa)(im)3]n(735452) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (735453). elements.content: Four novel compounds [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4′-bipy)2]n (1), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H2O)](H2O)}n, (2), [Ni(dpa)(im)3]n (3) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4) [H2dpa = 2,4′-diphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine, 2,2′-bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine and im = imidazole] were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. X-ray crystallography shows that the 2,4′-diphenic acid exhibits three coordination modes to link the metal ions: μ1−η1: η1/μ0−η0: η0, μ1−η1: η0/μ2−η1: η1 and μ1−η1: η0/μ1−η1: η0. Compound 1 has a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 are 3D supramolecular structures. Compound 4 is a 2D supramolecular structure. All the compounds, 1–4, are self-assembled to form supramolecular structures through hydrogen bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four novel compounds [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4'-bipy)2]n (1), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)](H2O)}n, (2), [Ni(dpa)(im)3]n (3) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4) [H2dpa = 2,4'-diphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, 2,2'-bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine and im = imidazole] were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. X-ray crystallography shows that the 2,4'-diphenic acid exhibits three coordination modes to link the metal ions: μ1-η1: η1/μ0-η0: η0, μ1-η1: η0/μ2-η1: η1 and μ1-η1: η0/μ1-η1: η0. Compound 1 has a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 are 3D supramolecular structures. Compound 4 is a 2D supramolecular structure. All the compounds, 1-4, are self-assembled to form supramolecular structures through hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures, based on metal and organic building blocks, is a rapidly expanding research area owing to the diverse topologies and potential application of these materials in luminescence, non-linear optics, catalysis and magnetism. [1–7]. Coordination polymers are synthesized by the rational selection of metal ions and the use of structurally interesting ligands with specific functionality to construct metal–organic frameworks. The synthesis of coordination polymers with fascinating structures requires careful selection of the organic ligands [8, 9].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures, based on metal and organic building blocks, is a rapidly expanding research area owing to the diverse topologies and potential application of these materials in luminescence, non-linear optics, catalysis and magnetism. [1-7]. Coordination polymers are synthesized by the rational selection of metal ions and the use of structurally interesting ligands with specific functionality to construct metal-organic frameworks. The synthesis of coordination polymers with fascinating structures requires careful selection of the organic ligands [8, 9].

elements.content: Hydrogen bonds are well-suited for the design of polymeric arrangements via crystal engineering because of their important directional interactions and because they interlink into 1-D or 2-D structures of high dimensionality [10–18]. As building blocks to construct coordination polymers, 2,4′-diphenyl-dicarboxylic acid (2,4′-H2dpa) is considered because (a) it affords various coordination modes due to its multifunctional carboxylate groups and can bridge metal ions, and (b) it is a flexible ligand that allows the formation of multi-dimensional structures constructed in different directions. To the best of our knowledge, there are no systematic studies of compounds with the 2,4′-H2dpa ligand that lead to supramolecular coordination polymers. Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of a series of compounds, [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4′-bipy)2] (1), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H2O)](H2O)}n, (2), [Ni(dpa) (im)3]n (3) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4).

As building blocks to construct coordination polymers, 2,4'-diphenyl-dicarboxylic acid (2,4'-H2dpa) is considered because (a) it affords various coordination modes due to its multifunctional carboxylate groups and can bridge metal ions, and (b) it is a flexible ligand that allows the formation of multi-dimensional structures constructed in different directions. To the best of our knowledge, there are no systematic studies of compounds with the 2,4'-H2dpa ligand that lead to supramolecular coordination polymers. Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of a series of compounds, [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4'-bipy)2] (1), {[Ni(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)](H2O)}n, (2), [Ni(dpa) (im)3]n (3) and [Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4).

Experimental

Materials

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the 400-4000 cm-1 range with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a dry KBr pellet.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.238 g), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol), 4,4’-bipy (0.156 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction products were red block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 51% based on Co). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C48 H34 CoN4O8: C, 67.53; H, 4.01; N, 6.56. Found: C, 67.60; H, 3.89; N, 6.64. IR (cm−1): 3402(br), 1619(s), 1481(s), 1164(w), 846(m), 660(m).

Synthesis

Synthesis of [Co(Hdpa) 2(4,4'-bipy)2]n (1)

The hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2⋅6H2O (1 mmol, 0.238 g), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol), 4,4'-bipy (0.156 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction products were red block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 51% based on Co). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C48 H34 CoN4O8: C, 67.53; H, 4.01; N, 6.56. Found: C, 67.60; H, 3.89; N, 6.64. IR (cm-1): 3402(br), 1619(s), 1481(s), 1164(w), 846(m), 660(m).

Green block crystals of 2 were obtained in 53% yield (based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C24H20NiN2O6: C, 58.69; H, 4.10; N, 5.70. Found: C, 57.92; H, 4.16; N, 5.75. elements.content: Single crystals were mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with a Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using an ω-scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [19]. All non-hydrogen atoms were located by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier syntheses. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were located by geometrical calculations and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structure refinement. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. All calculations were performed by the SHELXTL 97 program [20]. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analysis are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are shown in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals were mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with a Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using an ω-scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [19]. All non-hydrogen atoms were located by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier syntheses. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were located by geometrical calculations and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structure refinement. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. All calculations were performed by the SHELXTL 97 program [20]. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analysis are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are shown in Table 2.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description

[Co(Hdpa)2(4,4'-bipy)2]n (1)

The X-ray crystallographic study reveals that the 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, C2/c space group. Each Co(II) cation exhibits triangular prism geometry with an N2O4 coordination sphere from two dpa ligands [Co(1)-O(3) = 2.037(4) Å and Co(1)-O(4) = 2.315(6) Å] and two 4,4'-bipy ligands [Co-N = 2.101(4) Å] (Fig. 1a). Dpa ligands are coordinated to Co(II) in a bidentate chelating mode. The dihedral angles between the two phenyl rings in dpa and the two pyridine rings in 4,4'-bipy are 58.00° and 29.75°, respectively.

Figure 2a shows a perspective view of the title compound, {[Ni(dpa) (2,2′-bipy) (H2O)](H2O)}n with the numbering scheme. Ni(II) is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni–O = 2.043(15)–2.165(15) Å], two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)–N(1) = 2.059(16) Å and Ni(1)–N(2) = 2.064(16) Å] and one coordinated water molecule [Ni(1)–O(1w) = 2.071(15) Å], showing a distorted octahedral geometry. O(2), O(1w), N(1) and N(2) form the equatorial plane. The axial positions are occupied by two carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni(1)–O(1) = 2.165 (15) Å and Ni(1)–O(3) = 2.043(15) Å]. Dpa act as a μ3-ligand (μ1−η1: η0 and μ2−η1: η1) with one carboxylate group bridging two Ni(II)-atoms through a bis-monodentate mode, and the other carboxylate bridging bridging the second Ni(II)-atom through a monodentate mode. Moreover, each Ni(II)-atom center is connected with three dpa ligands. The organic ligands link the inorganic Ni(II) nodes to form a 2D sheet.

{[Ni(dpa) (2,2'-bipy) (H2O)](H2O)}n (2)

Figure 2a shows a perspective view of the title compound, {[Ni(dpa) (2,2'-bipy) (H2O)](H2O)}n with the numbering scheme. Ni(II) is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni-O = 2.043(15)-2.165(15) Å], two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)-N(1) = 2.059(16) Å and Ni(1)-N(2) = 2.064(16) Å] and one coordinated water molecule [Ni(1)-O(1w) = 2.071(15) Å], showing a distorted octahedral geometry. O(2), O(1w), N(1) and N(2) form the equatorial plane. The axial positions are occupied by two carboxylate oxygen atoms [Ni(1)-O(1) = 2.165 (15) Å and Ni(1)-O(3) = 2.043(15) Å]. Dpa act as a μ3-ligand (μ1-η1: η0 and μ2-η1: η1) with one carboxylate group bridging two Ni(II)-atoms through a bis-monodentate mode, and the other carboxylate bridging bridging the second Ni(II)-atom through a monodentate mode. Moreover, each Ni(II)-atom center is connected with three dpa ligands. The organic ligands link the inorganic Ni(II) nodes to form a 2D sheet.

elements.content: In compound 2, one lattice water takes part in hydrogen bonding through which the 2D sheet is extended into a 3D supramolecular network (Fig. 2b) with a H21w…O4 distance of 1.98 Å (symmetry code: −1/2 + x, 1/2 − y, −1/2 + z) and a H22w…O1 distance of 2.18 Å(symmetry code: −1 + x, y, z:) (Table 3).

elements.content: Complex 3 has a 3D supramolecular architecture derived from 1D helical chains via rich hydrogen bonds. Part of the chain with atom labeling is illustrated in Fig. 3a. The central Ni(1)-atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry in which the equatorial positions are occupied by two carboxyl oxygen atoms [Ni(1)–O(2) = 2.106(15) Å and Ni(1)–O(3) = 2.050 (16) Å] and two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)–N(3) = 2.068 (18) Å and Ni(1)–N(5) = 2.080(19) Å]. The axial positions are occupied by one water molecule [Ni(1)–O(1w) = 2.166(15) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Ni(1)–N(2) = 2.063(18) Å] with an O–Ni–N angle of 177.36 (6)°. The Ni ions are connected by dpa linkers to form a helical chain running along the [100] direction with a pitch of 13.824(5) Å. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle between them being 45.84°.
elements.clean_text:
[Ni(dpa)(im)3]n (3)

Complex 3 has a 3D supramolecular architecture derived from 1D helical chains via rich hydrogen bonds. Part of the chain with atom labeling is illustrated in Fig. 3a. The central Ni(1)-atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry in which the equatorial positions are occupied by two carboxyl oxygen atoms [Ni(1)-O(2) = 2.106(15) Å and Ni(1)-O(3) = 2.050 (16) Å] and two nitrogen atoms [Ni(1)-N(3) = 2.068 (18) Å and Ni(1)-N(5) = 2.080(19) Å]. The axial positions are occupied by one water molecule [Ni(1)-O(1w) = 2.166(15) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Ni(1)-N(2) = 2.063(18) Å] with an O-Ni-N angle of 177.36 (6)°. The Ni ions are connected by dpa linkers to form a helical chain running along the [100] direction with a pitch of 13.824(5) Å. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle between them being 45.84°.

elements.content: There exist in the complex intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Dpa is coordinated to a Ni center with each carboxylate group in a monodentate mode leaving the uncoordinated O-atom involved in hydrogen bonding to the neighboring dpa molecules [H(1w)…O(4) distance of 1.85 Å and H(2w)…O(1) distance of 1.79 Å]. There also exists an intermolecular hydrogen bond between the imidazole molecule and the coordinated oxygen atom [H(4A)…O(2) distance of 2.06 Å] (Fig. 3b). Intramolecular hydrogen bonds form between the N–H groups and the O-atom of dpa and the coordinated water with an H(1)…O(4) distance of 1.93 Å and an H(6A)…O(1w) distance of 2.07 Å (Table 3).
elements.clean_text: There exist in the complex intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Dpa is coordinated to a Ni center with each carboxylate group in a monodentate mode leaving the uncoordinated O-atom involved in hydrogen bonding to the neighboring dpa molecules [H(1w)…O(4) distance of 1.85 Å and H(2w)…O(1) distance of 1.79 Å]. There also exists an intermolecular hydrogen bond between the imidazole molecule and the coordinated oxygen atom [H(4A)…O(2) distance of 2.06 Å] (Fig. 3b). Intramolecular hydrogen bonds form between the N-H groups and the O-atom of dpa and the coordinated water with an H(1)…O(4) distance of 1.93 Å and an H(6A)…O(1w) distance of 2.07 Å (Table 3).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 4 consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(II)-atom, one imidazole ligand and three dpa ligands (Fig. 4a). The central Zn-atom is in a tetrahedral coordination environment having three Zn–O bonds with carboxylate groups [1.946(17)–1.981(16) Å] and one Zn–N bond from the imidazole ligand [Zn–N = 1.998(18) Å]. The bond angles between the donor atoms around the Zn(II) center range from 96.03° (7) to 132.22 (7)°. Dpa ligands bridge the two Zn(II) centers through μ1−η1:η0 and μ2−η1:η1 coordination modes. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle of 49.41°. The two coordination modes allows dpa to link the Zn(II) centers into a 1D chain containing repeating eight-membered (–Zn–O–C–O–) rings (Fig. 4b). The Zn…Zn separation in the rings is 3.644 Å.
elements.clean_text:
[Zn(dpa)(im)]n (4)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 4 consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(II)-atom, one imidazole ligand and three dpa ligands (Fig. 4a). The central Zn-atom is in a tetrahedral coordination environment having three Zn-O bonds with carboxylate groups [1.946(17)-1.981(16) Å] and one Zn-N bond from the imidazole ligand [Zn-N = 1.998(18) Å]. The bond angles between the donor atoms around the Zn(II) center range from 96.03° (7) to 132.22 (7)°. Dpa ligands bridge the two Zn(II) centers through μ1-η1:η0 and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes. A twisting between two phenyl rings in dpa is observed with the dihedral angle of 49.41°. The two coordination modes allows dpa to link the Zn(II) centers into a 1D chain containing repeating eight-membered (-Zn-O-C-O-) rings (Fig. 4b). The Zn…Zn separation in the rings is 3.644 Å.

elements.content: Crystal packing analysis of 4 shows the formation of interchain hydrogen bonds (Fig. 4c). The N–H group of the imidazole molecule of one chain is linked through the uncoordinated oxygen atom of the adjacent chain at a D…A distance of 2.729(3) and a N–H–O angle of 165° (symmetry code: x, −1 + y,−1 + z), which generates a two-dimensional structure (Table 3).

The N-H group of the imidazole molecule of one chain is linked through the uncoordinated oxygen atom of the adjacent chain at a D…A distance of 2.729(3) and a N-H-O angle of 165° (symmetry code: x, -1 + y,-1 + z), which generates a two-dimensional structure (Table 3).

elements.content: In the present work, four novel hydrogen bonding supramolecular networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. X-ray crystallography shows that compound 1 is a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 have a 3D supramolecular structure. Compound 4 has a 2D supramolecular structure. The successful preparation of these complexes provides a valuable approach to the construction of other supramolecular compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present work, four novel hydrogen bonding supramolecular networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. X-ray crystallography shows that compound 1 is a 1D supramolecular structure. Compounds 2 and 3 have a 3D supramolecular structure. Compound 4 has a 2D supramolecular structure. The successful preparation of these complexes provides a valuable approach to the construction of other supramolecular compounds.

The hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.238 g), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol), 4,4’-bipy (0.156 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction products were red block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 51% based on Co). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C48 H34 CoN4O8: C, 67.53; H, 4.01; N, 6.56. Found: C, 67.60; H, 3.89; N, 6.64. IR (cm−1): 3402(br), 1619(s), 1481(s), 1164(w), 846(m), 660(m).

Synthesis of {[Ni(dpa)(2,2′-bipy) (H<sub>2</sub>O)](H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub>n</sub>(<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of NiCl2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol), 2,2′-bipy (1 mmol, 0.156 g) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner. Green block crystals of 2 were obtained in 53% yield (based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C24H20NiN2O6: C, 58.69; H, 4.10; N, 5.70. Found: C, 57.92; H, 4.16; N, 5.75. IR (cm−1): 3460(br), 1645(s), 1446(s), 1216(w), 867(m), 642(m).

Synthesis of [Ni(dpa)(im)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was prepared in a similar manner as 2 except for the use of im instead of 2,2′-bipy. Green block crystals of 3 were obtained in 61% yield (based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C23 H22 Ni N6O5: C, 53.01; H, 4.25; N, 16.13. Found: C, 53.62; H, 4.19; N, 16.01. IR (cm−1): 1621(s), 1463(s), 1132(w), 821(m), 662(m).

Synthesis of [Zn(dpa)(im)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of ZnCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, g), H2dpa (0.242 g, 1 mmol), imidazole (0.136 g, 2 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction products were colorless block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give the pure product; yield, 60% (based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C17H12ZnN2O4: C, 54.65; H, 3.24; N, 7.50. Found: C, 53.76; H, 3.16; N, 7.42. IR (cm−1): 1626(s), 1452(s), 1165(w), 871(m), 639(m).
